intro: Craccina scopaeformis, commonly known as the scaly sandwort, is a small, flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its compact growth habit and succulent leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring or early summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Craccina scopaeformis is often found in rocky outcrops and along dry riverbeds.
